references: Pagels, John F. 1989. Distribution of the southeastern shrew, SOREX LONGIROSTRIS Bachman, in Western Virginia. Brimleyana. No. 15:123-131.

Fish and Wildlife Inventory of the Seven-County Region Included in the Central Florida Phosphate Industry Area-Wide Environmental Impact Study. Volumes I and II.  Also available as PB-278 457, Price codes: A99 in paper copy, A01 in microfiche. September 1977. Volume I - 643 p, 123 fig, 34 tab, Volume II - 635 p, 164 fig, 7 tab.
Hall, E. R. 1981. The Mammals of North America. Second edition. 2 Volumes. John Wiley and Sons, New York, New York. 1181 p.

Whitaker, J.O. Jr. and W.J. Hamilton, Jr. 1998.  Mammals of the eastern United States. Cornell Univ. Press, Ithaca, New York. 583 pp.
French, T.W. 1980. Sorex longirostris. Am. Soc. Mamm., Mammalian Species No. 143. pp. 1-3.
Jackson, H. H. T. 1928. A taxonomic review of the American long-tailed shrews (genera SOREX and MICROSOREX). North American Fauna 51:1-238.
Rose, R.K. 1980. The southeastern shrew, Sorex longirostis, in southern Indiana. Jour. Mamm. 61(1):162-164.
Jones, C. A., et al. 1991. Geographic variation and taxonomy of the southeastern shrew (SOREX LONGIROSTRIS). J. Mammalogy 72:263-272.
Webster, W. D., J. F. Parnell and W. C. Biggs Jr. 1985. Mammals of the Carolinas, Virginia, and Maryland. The University of North Carolina Press, Chapel Hill, NC.
George, S. B. 1988. Systematics, historical biogeography, and evolution of the genus SOREX. J. Mammalogy 69:443-461.
Taylor, C. L., and R. F. Wilkinson, Jr. 1988. First record of SOREX LONGIROSTRIS (Soricidae) in Oklahoma. Southwest. Nat. 33:248.

Pagels, J. F., C. S. Jones, and C. O. Handley, Jr. 1982. Northern limits of the southeastern shrew, SOREX LONGIROSTRIS Bachman (Insectivora:Soricidae) on the Atlantic coast of the United States. Brimleyana 8:51-59.

Junge, J. A., and R. S. Hoffmann. 1981. An annotated key to the long-tailed shrews (genus SOREX) of the United States and Canada, with notes on the Middle American SOREX. Occas. Pap. Univ. Kansas Mus. Nat. Hist. 94:1-48.
Layne, J. N., editor. 1978. Rare and endangered biota of Florida. Vol. 1. Mammals. State of Florida Game and Freshwater Fish Commission. xx + 52 pp.
Churchfield, S. 1992. The Natural History of Shrews. Cornell University Press, Ithaca, New York. 192 pp.
Wilson, D. E., and D. M. Reeder (editors). 1993. Mammal Species of the World:a Taxonomic and Geographic Reference. Second Edition. Smithsonian Institution Press, Washington, DC. xviii + 1206 pp.
Lowery, G. H., Jr. 1974. The mammals of Louisiana and its adjacent waters. Louisiana State University Press, Baton Rouge. 565 pp.

Lee, D. S., L. B. Funderburg Jr., and M. K. Clark. 1982. A distributional survey of North Carolina mammals. Occasional Papers of the North Carolina Biological Survey, No. 1982-10. North Carolina State. Mus. Nat. Hist., Raleigh, North Carolina. 72 pp.
habitat_description: Southeastern Shrews (Sorex longirostris) are found in moist, forested conditions, often near, but not restricted to, water bodies (Whitaker and Hamilton 1998).  They are perhaps most abundant in moist habitats with a dense ground cover of grasses, sedges, rushes, low-growing brush, and tangles of vines such as wooded swamps, marshes, and floodplain forest  (Jones and Birney 1998, Choate et al. 1994).  They are also found in upland habitats such as old fields, loblolly pine plantations, xeric hammock, sandpine scrub, pine flatwoods, and sandhills (Layne et al. 1977, French 1980).  Southeastern shrews are fossorial mammals that spend much of their time in underground burrows and in leaf litter.  Its range rarely overlaps that of S. cinereus.  Once considered rare, S. longirostris is generally uncommon, but is abundant in localized areas.  The young are born from April through October.  The litter size is 1-6 (average around 4) with 1-3 litters per year. Gestation probably lasts 2 - 3 weeks (if same as other shrews). Little is known about this species' life cycle. Stacy Smith, 12June05
